stem: The nurse is reviewing the electronic health record (EHR) of four different patients. Based on the information available in the EHR, indicate the most appropriate routine screening test for each patient.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
**07:00** Received report from night shift. Four patients require review for appropriate routine screenings. 

**Patient 1: Ms. Anya Sharma, DOB 03/15/1978.** Reports fatigue and occasional headaches. Family history of breast cancer in mother and aunt. 

**Patient 2: Mr. Ben Carter, DOB 09/22/1962.** Smoker (2 packs per day for 40 years). Reports a persistent cough. No significant family history. 

**Patient 3: Mr. Carl Davis, DOB 06/01/1952.** History of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Reports no new symptoms. Father had colon cancer at age 60. 

**Patient 4: Ms. Daisy Evans, DOB 11/08/2003.** Sexually active. Reports using condoms inconsistently. No significant family history. Expresses concerns about STIs.

**07:30** Initiated review of patient charts. Will consult with provider regarding any necessary screening orders. Documented patient education materials available on preventative screenings. Awaiting provider orders.

columns.text: Low-dose CT Scan of the Chest

rationale.correct: The correct answers align with the recommended routine screenings based on the patient's age, sex, risk factors, and medical history. Ms. Sharma requires a mammogram due to her age and family history of breast cancer. Mr. Carter requires a low-dose CT scan of the chest due to his smoking history. Mr. Davis requires a colonoscopy due to his age, family history of colon cancer, and history of hyperlipidemia. Ms. Evans requires Chlamydia and Gonorrhea screening due to her age and sexual activity.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect answers do not align with the recommended routine screenings based on the patient's age, sex, risk factors, and medical history. Selecting an incorrect screening could lead to a delay in diagnosis and treatment of a potential health issue.

answerBreakdown.text: Ms. Anya Sharma (48 years old, family history of breast cancer)
answerBreakdown.rationale: According to the American Cancer Society, women aged 45-54 should get mammograms every year. Because Ms. Sharma is 48 and has a family history of breast cancer, she should be getting annual mammograms.

answerBreakdown.text: Mr. Ben Carter (64 years old, 40-year smoking history)
answerBreakdown.rationale: The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends annual screening for lung cancer with low-dose computed tomography (LDCT) in adults aged 50 to 80 years who have a 20 pack-year smoking history and currently smoke or have quit within the past 15 years.

answerBreakdown.text: Mr. Carl Davis (74 years old, history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and family history of colon cancer)
answerBreakdown.rationale: Guidelines recommend regular colon cancer screening starting at age 45. Given his age (74) and family history, colonoscopy is the most appropriate screening method to visualize the colon and detect any abnormalities.

answerBreakdown.text: Ms. Daisy Evans (20 years old, sexually active)
answerBreakdown.rationale: The CDC recommends annual chlamydia and gonorrhea screening for all sexually active women younger than 25 years. Ms. Evans is 20 years old and sexually active, and should be screened annually.

clinicalPearls: Routine screenings are essential for early detection and prevention of various health conditions.
Screening guidelines vary based on age, sex, risk factors, and medical history.
Nurses play a crucial role in educating patients about the importance of routine screenings and ensuring they receive appropriate care.

questionTrap.trap: Students might select screenings based solely on age, without considering other risk factors such as family history or smoking history.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully review all patient information, including age, sex, risk factors, and medical history, before selecting the most appropriate screening test.

mnemonic.title: SCREEN
mnemonic.expansion: Screening saves lives, Consider risk factors, Review guidelines, Educate patients, Ensure follow-up, Never forget preventative care.
